sen.j: 流派（りゅうは）とは日本の芸道や酒造りなどの分野においてひとつの体系化された技（技術、技能）を継承する家元、宗家などを頂点とした集団のことをいう。
sen.e: Ryuha is a pyramid structured group of people with Iemoto (head of school) or Soke (grand master) situated at the top of the group, who succeeds a certain systematized waza (craftsmanship or technique) in the fields of Japanese art, sake brewing, etc.

Ryuha are groups of people that are headed by an Iemoto (head of school) or Soke (grand master), who passes down a certain systematic waza (craftsmanship or technique) in the fields of Japanese art, sake brewing, etc.

It can be called ryugi, too.

sen.j: 流派とは、能（猿楽）、狂言、日本舞踊、棒の手、華道（生け花）、茶道（茶の湯）、包丁式、有職故実、衣紋道、雅楽、書道、日本画、剣術・抜刀術・薙刀術・弓術・砲術・軍学（兵法）などの日本武術などの芸道や日本酒造りなどの分野において、ひとつの体系化された技を継承する集団を指し、開祖の家元・宗家とその門弟により継承される。
sen.e: Ryuha is a group of people which succeed a certain systematized expertise or technique in the field of sake brewing and Japanese art including No (Sarugaku (form of entertainment which was popular in Japan in 11th to 14th centuries)), Kyogen (traditional short comedic drama), Nihon Buyo (classical Japanese dance), Bo-no-te (Japanese traditional dance), Kado (Japanese flower arrangement), Sado (tea ceremony), Hochoshiki (schools of Japanese cuisine), Yusoku Kojitsu (research of government posts, ceremonies and clothing based on past performance or practice), Emondo (traditional technique of dressing up for Junihitoe (a ceremonial Robe of a court lady)), Garaku (Japanese traditional music and dance), shodo (calligraphy), Nihonga (Japanese-style painting) and Japanese martial arts such as kenjutsu (swordplay), battojutsu (the technique of drawing a sword), naginata jutsu (art of using a naginata halberd), kyujutsu (archery), hojutsu (gunnery) and gungaku (art of warfare), and is succeeded by the Iemoto or Soke of the founder or their disciples.

sen.j: 日本武術以外の芸道の流派では、開祖の家系により、家元の宗家の地位を世襲する一子相伝（全伝）の流派継承と門人への流派免許を与える家元制がとられている。
sen.e: In groups or schools other than the Japanese martial arts, there are two Iemoto systems, one of which is to allow the founder's family to succeed the Iemoto Soke position, that is called Isshi Soden and another of which is to grant a license of the school to their disciples.

In ryuha other than those of the Japanese martial arts, there are two Iemoto systems, one where the the founder's family inherits the Iemoto Soke position, known as Isshi Soden, and the other where a school license is granted to a student.

sen.j: 日本武術では柳生氏など家元制もあるが、おおむね最もその道に長け人物ともに申し分ない高弟の中から免許皆伝者を選びを継承される。
sen.e: In the Japanese martial art, the Yagyu clan has maintained the Iemoto system, but in general, a high-caliber disciple is appointed as a person qualified with Menkyo-kaiden (full proficiency) to succeed the school.

sen.j: なお近代に成立の武道では柔道、剣道、弓道などは流派という概念を否定した。
sen.e: In the modern-created martial art, Judo, Kendo (Japanese fencing) and Kyudo (Japanese archery) do not maintain the conception of Ryuha.
